Fig. 5 Fig. 6 (A) Toluene and (B) CO2 desorption in Toluene-TPD profiles of (a) meso-TiO2-CeO2 and (b) Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2. Technology, College of Materials Science and Engineering, Beijing University of Technology, Beijing 100124, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. The major challenges encountered in developing catalysts for volatile organic compound (VOCs) treatments by catalytic oxidation are related to the low-temperature oxidation performance and water resistance. To address these issues, we herein develop an in situ hard-templating method to prepare the Pt or Pd/mesoporous TiO2-CeO2 catalyst and apply it for the oxidation of toluene. It was found that the Pt/mesoporous TiO2-CeO2 catalyst exhibited outstanding catalytic performance and stability under the high humidity (15 vol% H2O) condition. Various characterization results revealed that the Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic activity: the temperatures at toluene conversions of 50 and 90 % were 195 and 214 °C at a space velocity of 30,000 mL g−1 h−1, with the TOFPt values and specific reaction rates at 160 and 180 °C being 70.34 × 10−3 and 153.13 × 10−3 s−1, and 1.80 and 3.92 mmol gPt −1 s−1, respectively. Such excellent performance of Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 was related to its high surface area, abundant oxygen vacancies, high active oxygen species concentration, good low-temperature reducibility, and strong interaction between Pt or Pd and meso-TiO2-CeO2. The mechanism of toluene oxidation might take place via the following route: Toluene is first oxidized to benzyl alcohol and benzoquinone, then converted to benzaldehyde, benzoic acid, maleic anhydride, and these intermediates are finally oxidized to CO2 and H2O. Graphical Abstract The Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 catalyst is prepared using the in situ hard-templating method. The results reveal that Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 performs the best for toluene oxidation and exhibits good water resistance under the high humidity (up to 15 vol%) condition. Keywords Supported noble metal catalyst Mesoporous titania-ceria In situ hard-templating method Toluene oxidation High humidity Water resistance Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction With the rapid development of urbanization and industrialization, there has been a significant increase in the emission of volatile organic compounds (VOCs), which threaten the atmospheric environment and human health. Therefore, the VOCs are urgently needed to eliminate. Among the VOCs elimination technologies, catalytic oxidation has been widely used because of its advantages of high removal efficiency, low energy consumption, and no secondary pollution, in which the key issue of this technology is the development of high-performance catalysts. Due to the excellent low-temperature catalytic activities, the supported noble metal catalysts were widely applied in many reactions. For example, Zhou et al. [1] prepared the Pt-Co/hollow multi-shelled CeO2 for the highly efficient toluene oxidation, and observed that the PtCo3/CeO2 catalyst showed the excellent catalytic performance (T 90 % = 158°C at space velocity (SV) = 36000 mL g−1 h−1), long-term stability, and good water resistance. With the rise in reaction temperature, the size of Au in Au/γ-Al2O3 increased from 3.2 to 6.6 nm, the catalytic activity was gradually decreased for CO oxidation [2]. The similar phenomenon was observed in catalytic NO oxidation over the PdPt/SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts [3], which was due to the aggregation of precious metals at higher temperatures that caused the catalytic activity to drop. If a special material was used to confine the precious metal, it would avoid the aggregation of the precious metal, thus maintaining the excellent catalytic performance. Mesoporous mixed metal oxides have been gained much attention due to their unique properties. Furthermore, the interconnected ordered mesoporous nanostructures of mesoporous mixed metal oxides possess better mass-transfer efficiencies and adsorption-desorption properties compared with their nonporous counterparts. More interestingly, the crystalline mesoporosity of mixed metal oxides can provide an optimal nanoscale-confined environmental to prepare high-performance catalysts. For example, Wang et al. [4] prepared the meso-Pt@Ag catalysts for the electrocatalytic oxidation of ethanol using the hard templating- and in situ reduction-combined strategy, and found that the as-obtained catalysts showed the excellent catalytic activity in the alkaline electrolyte, good stability, and strong toxicity resistance to carbonaceous intermediates. Kumar et al. [5] synthesized the meso-Pt-ZSM-5, micro-Pt-ZSM-5, and micro-Pt-Beta catalysts for the dehydrogenation of propane, and observed that meso-Pt-ZSM-5 exhibited the excellent selectivity and stability. Lv et al. [6,7] fabricated the fcc-meso-Pd, hcp-meso-Pd x B y , and meso-Pd/PtSn catalysts, which showed the excellent catalytic activity for the reduction of nitrophenol, and provided a new way for the conversion from fcc to hcp. Lei et al. [8] synthesized a CuO x - MnO x catalyst, which exhibited excellent catalytic oxidation activity towards toluene and acetone. The temperatures at which 90 % conversion was achieved (T 90 %) for toluene and acetone were 216°C and 176°C respectively. Moreover, the catalyst could still maintain good catalytic oxidation performance in the presence of 10 vol% water. However, as the water concentration increased, the catalytic activity began to decline. The water tolerance of catalysts plays a pivotal role in establishing efficient VOCs oxidation systems. To mitigate H2O-induced catalyst deactivation, the current strategies for addressing water resistance primarily focus on three key aspects: structural optimization, hydrophobic material design, and active site engineering [9]. Representative studies demonstrate these strategies: Chen et al. [10] developed a Pd@NC/BN-2 composite catalyst that significantly reduces energy barriers for H2O dissociation and O2 activation. The hydrophobic h-BN substrate synergizes with the spatial confinement effects of the NC layer to prevent water molecule aggregation at active interfaces. Meanwhile, Lu et al. [11] achieved remarkable water resistance through in situ encapsulation of cobalt-palladium bimetallic species within HZSM-5 zeolite via a one-pot hydrothermal synthesis. Sun et al. [12] engineered a Pt-Pd bimetallic-supported V2O5-TiO2 catalyst, where the three-dimensional confinement architecture and strong metal-support interaction effectively inhibit hydrothermal particle agglomeration. Notably, this catalyst maintains exceptional stability even under harsh hydrothermal conditions (245°C, 5 vol% H2O). While these advancements have improved catalyst water resistance, critical challenges persist in developing high-performance hydrophobic materials for high-humidity environments and establishing cost-effective preparation processes. According to the literature results, we know that precious metals have the unsaturated state d electron orbits [13], which can effectively promote the adsorption and activation of VOCs and O2, thus showing good catalytic activities for the elimination of VOCs in low temperatures. Due to the outstanding oxygen storage capacity and abundant surface oxygen vacancies [14], ceria-based materials are usually used as supports. TiO2 is combined with ceria can generate the mixed metal oxide material suitable for the use of a support. Thus, we selected Pt as the noble metal, Ce and Ti as the second or third metal to dope into the Pt to obtain meso-Pt-Ti-CeO2 by in-situ confined KIT-6. In this work, we prepared the mesoporous titania-ceria-supported Pt catalysts using the in situ confine-doping method, characterized their physicochemical properties, evaluated their catalytic activities for toluene oxidation, and examined the resistance to water with the concentrations of 1.0–15.0 vol%. It was found that the mesoporous titania-ceria-supported Pt catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic performance and good water resistance for toluene oxidation. Therefore, this work was of novelty and practical significance in designing the water-resistant catalysts for catalytic VOCs oxidation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Synthesis of mesoporous ceria (meso-CeO2) using the in situ hard-templating method. First, the hard template KIT-6 was synthesized using a previously method [15]. After that, the KIT-6 was used to fabricate the meso-CeO2. Specifically, 1 g of KIT-6 template was dissolved in 20 mL of ethanol solution, sonicated for 30 min, and stirred in a water bath at 65°C for another 30 min. Subsequently, 2 g of Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O was added to the above mixed solution, sonicated for 30 min, and stirred continuously in a water bath at 65°C until the solution was completely dry. The dried solid was placed in a ceramic crucible and thermally treated in a muffle furnace at a ramp of 2 °C min−1 from room temperature (RT) to 550°C and maintained in air at 550°C for 6 h. After cooling to RT, the sample was etched with a hot NaOH aqueous solution (2.0 mol L−1) at 80°C for 30 min to remove the KIT-6 template, the precipitates were collected by centrifugation, washed three times with deionized water and ethanol, and finally dried in an oven at 80°C for 12 h, thus obtaining the light yellow meso-CeO2 support. Synthesis of mesoporous titania-ceria (meso-TiO2-CeO2) using the in situ hard-templating method. The procedures of meso-TiO2-CeO2 synthesis were the same as those of meso-CeO2 synthesis, except that 174.20 mg of butyl titanate and 2 g of Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O were simultaneously added to the KIT-6-containing mixed solution. Preparation of the Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 (theoretical Pt doping = ca. 1 wt%) catalyst using the in situ hard-templating method. The procedures of Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 preparation were similar to those of meso-CeO2 synthesis, except that (i) 174.20 mg of butyl titanate, 2 g of Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O, and 22.15 mg of K2PtCl6 were simultaneously added to the KIT-6-containing mixed solution; and (ii) the obtained mixed solid was thermally treated in an air flow of 30 mL min−1 in a muffle furnace at 800°C for 6 h. For the comparison purpose, we also prepared the Pd/meso-TiO2-CeO2 (theoretical Pd doping = ca. 1 wt%) catalyst using the in situ hard-templating method (with PdN4H12Cl2 as the Pd precursor) same as that adopted in Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 preparation. According to the inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopic (ICP-AES) characterization results, one can realize that the actual Pt and Ti contents in Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 were 0.94 and 2.92 wt%, while the actual Pd and Ti contents in Pd/meso-TiO2-CeO2 were 0.75 and 3.15 wt% ( Table 1), respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Physicochemical properties of all of the catalysts were determined using numerous techniques, such as ICP-AES, X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 adsorption-desorption (BET), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Raman spectra, electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), O2 temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD), toluene temperature-programmed desorption (Toluene-TPD), and in situ diffuse reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (in situ DRIFTS). The detailed characterization procedures are stated in the Supplementary material. 2.3 Catalytic activity evaluation Catalytic activities of the catalysts for toluene oxidation were assessed in the continuous flow fixed-bed quartz tubular microreactor (inner diameter = 20 mm) at atmospheric pressure. 200 mg of the catalyst (40–60 mesh) was diluted with 1.0 g of quartz sand (40–60 mesh) to minimize the effect of hot spots. The reactant mixture was composed of 700 ppm toluene and air (balance), and the total flow rate was 100 mL min−1, in which the toluene/O2 molar ratio and SV were 1/280 and ca. 30,000 mL g−1 h−1, respectively. The 700 ppm toluene was generated by passing a N2 flow of 3.6 mL min−1 through a pure toluene-containing bottle that was chilled in an ice–water isothermal bath at 0°C. The alteration in SV was achieved by changing the air flow rates. The gas chromatograph (GC-9790 PLUS, Fuli, China) was adopted online for the monitoring of the changes in toluene concentration. Toluene conversions were calculated according to the toluene concentration changes in the inlet and outlet of the microreactor. The catalytic activities were evaluated by the temperatures (T 50 % and T 90 %) at which 50 and 90 % of toluene conversions were achieved, respectively. We can verify the absence of mass transfer limitations under reaction conditions experimentally and theoretically. Upon estimating the Damköhler number under the most unfavorable circumstances, it becomes evident that the external diffusion mass transfer resistance in the reaction system was negligible. To assess whether there are internal mass transfer limitations or not, it is advisable to conduct a Weisz-Prater analysis. In line with the Weisz-Prater criterion, when the dimensionless Weisz-Prater parameter (NW-P) has a value lower than 0.3, it can be regarded as a sufficient condition indicating the absence of significant pore diffusion limitation. In the cases of our catalytic reaction systems, i.e., toluene was oxidized at 205 °C over the Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2, Pd/meso-TiO2-CeO2, meso-TiO2-CeO2, meso-CeO2 or meso-TiO2 sample, the NW–P value was calculated to be 4.72 × 10−11, which was much less than 0.3. According to the Maxwell-Gilliland formula and Nusselt number (details of the calculations are stated in Supplementary material), we calculated the effective diffusivity. The Damköhler number and Weisz-Prater parameter were also estimated under the most unfavorable conditions. The results confirm that there was negligible external or internal diffusion (mass transfer resistance) under the adopted reaction conditions. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Crystal phase composition, pore structure, and morphology Fig. 1A illustrates the synthesis process of the Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 sample. The Pt/TiO2-CeO2@KIT-6 precursor was etched with a hot NaOH aqueous solution (2.0 mol L−1) at 80 °C for 30 min to remove the KIT-6 template, thus obtaining the Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 catalyst. As shown in the TEM images of the as-obtained samples (Fig. 1B-D), all of the samples displayed a mesoporous structure. Fig. S1 presents N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore-size distributions of the samples, and BET surface areas, average pore diameters, and pore volumes of the samples are summarized in Table 1. Each of the samples exhibited a type IV isotherm with an H1 hysteresis loop in the relative pressure (p/p0) range of 0.5–1.0, indicating the formation of a mesoporous structure [16]. BET surface areas (145–151 m2 g−1), pore volumes (0.23–0.26 cm3 g−1), and average pore sizes (7.3–7.6 nm) of the meso-TiO2, meso-CeO2, and meso-TiO2-CeO2 samples were slightly higher or bigger than those (140–141 m2 g−1, 0.20–0.21 cm3 g−1, and 6.9–7.1 nm) of the Pd/meso-TiO2-CeO2 and Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 samples, respectively. According to the ICP-AES characterization results, the actual Ti content in meso-TiO2-CeO2 was 2.89 wt%, i.e., Ti/Ce molar ratio was 0.15:1.00; the actual Pd and Ti contents in Pd/meso-TiO2-CeO2 were 0.75 and 3.15 wt%, respectively, i.e., Pd/Ti/Ce molar ratio was 0.02:0.15:1.00; and the real Pt and Ti contents in Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 were 0.94 and 2.92 wt%, respectively, i.e., Pd/Ti/Ce molar ratio was 0.01/0.15/1.00. By measuring the aligned lattice fringes of Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2, we can realize that the lattice spacings are approximately 0.330, 0.291, 0.324, and 0.196 nm (Fig. 1E), in which the lattice spacings of 0.330 and 0.291 nm corresponded to the (111) and (200) crystal planes of CeO₂; the lattice spacing of 0.324 nm was due to the (110) crystal plane of TiO2; and the lattice spacing of 0.196 nm was owing to the (200) crystal plane of Pt. The distributions of the elements shown in Fig. 1G clearly reveal that the Ce, Ti, and Pt elements are uniformly dispersed in the Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 sample. Fig. 2A shows XRD profiles of the meso-CeO2, meso-Ti-CeO2, Pd/meso-TiO2-CeO2, and Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2. Compared with the XRD pattern (JCPDS PDF # 34–0394) of the standard cubic CeO2 sample, all of the diffraction peaks matched those of the cubic fluorite-type ceria, and no other diffraction peaks were observed. This result was attributed to the low doping and good dispersion of the noble metal (Pt or Pd) and titania. In other words, the doping of titania to ceria or loading of Pt or Pd did not significantly alter the crystal structure of ceria. It is noted that there was a slight shift in the peak assignable to the (111) crystal plane of the meso-TiO2-CeO2, Pd/meso-TiO2-CeO2 or Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 sample, indicating a part of Pt or Pd and a part of Ti was incorporated of into the CeO2 lattice [17]. Using the Scherrer equation, we can calculate the grain dimensions of the meso-TiO2-CeO2, Pd/meso-TiO2-CeO2, and Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 samples, as listed in Table 1. The grain sizes of these samples were in the range of 2.5–3.2 nm. In general, the smaller grain size was associated with an increased number of exposed defect site, which favors the enhancement in catalytic activity [18]. The increased lattice spacing (standard d 111 = 0.312 nm) and lattice distortion/deformation can be attributed to the formation of oxygen vacancies and the partial reduction of Ce4+ during the annealing process, creating the additional active sites and further enhancing catalytic activity of the Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 sample [19]. In order to obtain defect information, we used the Raman technique to detect the changes of chemical bond vibrational signals [20]. The Raman spectrum of meso-TiO2 (Fig. 2B) shows the typical bands of the anatase phase: 193 cm−1 (E g), 393 cm−1 (B 1 g), 517 cm−1 (A 1 g), and 635 cm−1 (E g), which represented a symmetry of the positive border [21,22]. The E g band was associated with the symmetric stretching vibration of O-Ti-O in TiO2, the B 1 g band was caused by the symmetric bending vibration of O-Ti-O, and the A 1 g band was due to the antisymmetric bending vibration of O-Ti-O [23]. The Raman spectrum of meso-ceria (Fig. 2B) shows a typical band of the cubic fluorite-type phase: 458 cm−1 (F 2 g), which was consistent with the XRD result of ceria [24]. With the doping of titania and loading of precious metal (Pd or Pt), the F 2 g characteristic band intensity of ceria weakened, and the A 1 g characteristic band intensity of titania was enhanced, which was due to the strong interaction resulting from the doping of titania and loading of Pd or Pt. It can also be inferred that the loading of noble metal increases the asymmetrical stretching vibration of O-Ti-O, Pt-O-Ti or Pt-O-Ce. 3.2 Surface element composition, metal oxidation state, and oxygen species XPS was used to determine surface properties of the catalysts. Fig. 3 shows the Ce 3d, Ti 2p, Pt 4 f, and Pd 3d XPS spectra of the samples, with the corresponding surface element compositions being summarized in Table 2. Fig. 3 A displays the Ce 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 states, which included two sets of signals: The former contained the 3d3/2 features at binding energy (BE) = 897.4, 900.8, 903.1, 907.6, and 916.4 eV; and the latter contains the Ce 3d5/2 features at BE = 879.8, 882.2, 884.2, 888.7, and 898.1 eV. The signals at BE = 879.8, 897.4, 884.2 and 903.1 eV were assigned to the surface Ce3+ species, whereas the others were ascribable to the surface Ce4+ species [25,26]. The Ti 2p spectra of the samples show a distinct split of spin-orbit components, with the peaks at BE = 458.2 and 463.9 eV corresponding to the Ti 2p3/2 and Ti 2p1/2 states of the surface Ti4+ species, respectively, and the peaks at BE = 456.8 and 462.4 eV can be attributed to the surface Ti3+ species. A BE shift of −0.3 eV in comparison to the BE of the typical titanium common chemical state suggests the formation of bulk-like TiO2 with oxygen vacancies [27]. For the Pd 3d XPS spectrum of the Pd/meso-TiO2-CeO2 sample, three valence states of Pd (Pd4+, Pd2+, and Pd0) species were detected. The peaks located at BE = 335.6 and 340.8 eV were assigned to the surface metallic Pd0 species, the ones at BE = 336.6 and 341.8 eV were ascribed to the surface Pd2+ species, and the other doublet ones at BE = 337.7 and 343 eV were attributed to the surface Pd4+ species [28]. Compared to the common chemical states of Pd4+, Pd2+, and Pd0, this sample showed a shift to a higher BE (ΔE b = +0.4 eV), which could be ascribed to the decrease of cluster sizes or the charge transfer between Pd and TiO2-CeO2 [29] Moreover, the Pd on the Pd/meso-TiO2-CeO2 sample was mainly the Pd4+ and Pd2+ species, together with a small amount of the metallic Pd0 species. The Pt 4 f XPS spectra of the Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 sample are illustrated in Fig. 3 C. Based on the results reported in the previous literature [30,31], each of the Pt 4 f XPS spectra can be decomposed into six components. The components at BE = 71.0 and 74.3 eV were assigned to the surface metallic Pt0 species, the ones at BE = 72.3 and 75.6 eV were attributed to the surface Pt2+ species, and the ones at BE = 73.8 and 77.1 eV were ascribed to the surface Pt4+ species. Notably, the BEs of Pt 4 f, Pd 3d, Ti 2p, and Ce 3d in all of the samples exhibited a shift (ΔE b = −0.1, +0.4, −0.3, and +0.1 eV, respectively) compared with the BEs of their common chemical states, suggesting the existent of an enhanced electron transfer among Pt or Pd and TiO2-CeO2 due to the stronger orbital interaction. Additionally, quantitatively analyzing the XPS peaks of the samples can provide the surface element compositions, as listed in Table 2. With the loading of Pd or Pt, the Ti3+/Ti4+ or Ce3+/Ce4+ molar ratio increased. The Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 sample showed the highest surface Ti3+/Ti4+ and Ce3+/Ce4+ molar ratios among all of the samples, indicating the presence of the largest amount of oxygen vacancies in this sample (which was beneficial for O2 adsorption and activation). This result was consistent with the O 1 s and EPR results shown below. After the reaction, the surface adsorbed oxygen species were consumed, the concentration of Ce3+ species and the amount of oxygen vacancies increased, and thus maintained the good catalytic activity. The results are listed in Table S1. The types of oxygen species on the surface of the as-obtained samples were explored using the EPR technique, and their EPR spectra are shown in Fig. 4A. EPR is an effective technique to detect the paramagnetic species containing unpaired electrons. EPR can be used to excavate the reactive oxygen species: superoxide (O2− ) species, singlet oxygen (1O2*) species, adsorbed mono-oxygen (O−) species, and oxygen vacancies on the surface of a catalyst [32]. The symmetric signals at g = 1.96 and 2.03 belonged to the Ce3+-O-Ce4+ type defect sites and O2 − [33,34]. Also, there was a symmetrical signal at g = 2.003, which was mainly due to the presence of unpaired electrons at the oxygen vacancies [35]. The intensity of the signal at g = 1.96 of the Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 sample was higher than that of the meso-TiO2-CeO2 and meso-CeO2 samples, indicating an increase in the Ce3+ defect site of meso-CeO2 after the loading of Pt and the doping of titania, which was consistent with the XPS results described above. As shown in Fig. 4B, the asymmetric O 1 s spectrum of each sample could be decomposed into four components at BE = 529.4, 530.6, 531.8, and 535.1 eV, attributable to the surface lattice oxygen (Olatt), defective oxygen, surface adsorbed oxygen (Oads, e.g., O2 −, O2 2− or O−), and hydroxyl group or adsorbed molecular water [36,37], respectively. The Ov/Ototal or Oads/Ototal molar ratio increased with the loading of Pt. Compared to the Ov/Olatt and Oads/Ototal molar ratios (14.2 and 31.0) of the Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 sample, those (12.4–12.8 and 28.7–28.9) of the meso-TiO2-CeO2 and Pd/meso-TiO2-CeO2 samples were lower, respectively. Clearly, the increase in Ov/Ototal or Oads/Ototal molar ratio with the loading of Pt confirmed the generation of the large oxygen vacancies and rich active oxygen species on the surface of this sample. According to the literature, a higher concentration of Oads species on the surface of a catalyst would be beneficial for the improvement in catalytic activity for the total oxidation of toluene [38]. Compared with the other samples, the loading of Pt could promote the activation of oxygen molecules, making the Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 sample possess the strongest ability to adsorb and activate oxygen molecules. Fig. 4C illustrates O2-TPD profiles of the samples. A oxygen desorption peak appeared at ca. 129 and 647 °C, which was attributed to the desorption of the surface adsorbed oxygen species and surface lattice oxygen species on the meso-CeO2 sample, respectively. With the loading of Pt or Pd and the doping of titania, the desorption peak was shifted to a lower temperature, which was due to the weakening of the Ce-O-Ce bond and the increase in the interaction of Pt and meso-TiO2-CeO2 (which resulted in the enhanced oxygen desorption). Notably, the emergence of dual desorption peaks within the 250–500°C range for Pd/Pt-doped catalysts may be ascribed to the restructuring of surface active sites induced by strong metal-support interactions, thereby enhancing the diversity of surface oxygen species [39]. The amount of oxygen desorption below 500 °C increased in the order of meso-CeO2 (122.80 mmol g−1) < meso-TiO2-CeO2 (140.73 mmol g−1) < Pd/meso-TiO2-CeO2 (180.43 mmol g−1) < Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 (183.09 mmol g−1), which was in good agreement with the XPS results. Since a more amount of oxygen desorption is beneficial for the enhancement in activity of a catalyst [40], it is understandable that the Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 sample performs the best in toluene oxidation. 3.3 Reducibility and toluene adsorption and desorption behaviors Shown in Fig. 5 are H2-TPR profiles of the samples. As can be observed from Fig. 5 A, the meso-CeO2 sample displayed a strong peak at 502°C, attributable to the reduction of bulk Ce4+ to Ce3+ [41]. With the doping of titania, the reduction peaks were shifted to lower temperatures due to the weakening of the Ce-O bond, which caused the mobility of the surface lattice oxygen species to increase. With the loading of Pt, the reduction peak temperature was further shifted to 225°C, which was owing to the strong interaction between Pt and meso-TiO2-CeO2. Noble metals function as activation centers for H2 dissociation, inducing hydrogen spillover that dramatically enhances the reducibility of CeO2. This catalytic process thereby shifts the characteristic CeO2 reduction peak into the low-temperature regime, ultimately rendering it unresolvable in H2-TPR profiles due to coalescence with inter-facial reduction features [42]. After quantitative analysis on the reduction peaks in H2-TPR profiles of the samples, we calculate H2 consumption of the samples, as listed in Table 2. Apparently, H2 consumption below 400°C increased in the order of meso-CeO2 (0.07 mmol gcat −1) < meso-TiO2-CeO2 (0.08 mmol gcat −1) < Pd/meso-TiO2-CeO2 (0.45 mmol gcat −1) < Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 (0.65 mmol gcat −1). As shown in Fig. 5B, the initial H2 consumption rate also increased in the same sequence. That is to say, the Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 sample possessed the best low-temperature reducibility. Illustrated in Fig. 6 A and B are toluene-TPD profiles of the samples. The desorption temperature of toluene from the meso-TiO2-CeO2 sample was 73°C. With the loading of Pt, the desorption temperature of toluene was moved to a lower temperature (66°C) for the Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 sample (Fig. 6 A). As for the desorption of CO2 from the samples (Fig. 6B), there were three desorption regions in the ranges of below 250°C, 250–730°C, and above 730°C, which were due to the reactions of the surface adsorbed oxygen species (at 66°C), surface lattice oxygen species (at 250–730°C), and bulk lattice oxygen species (730–900°C) with the adsorbed toluene. By quantitatively analyzing the toluene desorption peak areas, one can realize that toluene desorption of the Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 sample was larger than that of the meso-TiO2-CeO2 sample, i.e., the former possessed a larger toluene adsorption capacity than the latter. This conclusion was confirmed by the result obtained from Fig. S2, where the intensity of adsorption band increased with the extension of adsorption time, indicating a growing amount of the adsorbed toluene. Subsequently, with the introduction of N2 flow, the weakly adsorbed toluene was removed, confirming that Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 possessed a large toluene adsorption capacity, which was beneficial for the improvement in catalytic activity for toluene oxidation. 3.4 Catalytic performance Toluene oxidation was selected as a model reaction to evaluate catalytic performance of the samples. Fig. 7 A shows catalytic activities of the samples at SV = 30,000 mL g−1 h−1. At low temperatures, toluene and oxygen adsorb onto the sample surface, facilitating the oxidation of toluene. With the rise in temperature, toluene conversion increased continuously. For the convenience of comparison, the reaction temperatures (T 50 %, and T 90 %) at toluene conversions of 50 and 90 % ( Table 3) were used to evaluate catalytic activity of the sample, respectively. Apparently, the Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 sample showed the highest catalytic activity with the T 50 %, and T 90 % of 195 and 214°C (which were much lower than those (216–234 and 251–350°C) of the other samples) at SV = 30,000 mL g−1 h−1, respectively. As shown in Fig. S3, the CO2 selectivity of catalyst was consistent with the trend of catalytic activity. With the temperature rising, the production of CO2 gradually rises. At 220℃, the selectivity reaches as high as 90 % of the Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2, domenstrating that toluene is almost completely oxidized into CO2 and H2O [43]. Based on the Arrhenius curves for toluene oxidation of the samples (Fig. 7B), their apparent activation energies (E a) were calculated. To accurately calculate activation energy through an Arrhenius plot, it is essential to prioritize data points with less-than-20 % conversion rates. This selective approach ensures the analysis primarily focuses on the system intrinsic kinetic behavior while effectively minimizing interference from external factors. The E a value decreased in the following order of meso-TiO2 (185 kJ mol−1) > meso-CeO2 (144 kJ mol−1) > meso-TiO2-CeO2 (131 kJ mol−1) > Pd/meso-TiO2-CeO2 (119 kJ mol−1) > Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 (71 kJ mol−1), which was consistent with their catalytic activity sequence (Table 3). Catalytic activities of the meso-CeO2 and meso-TiO2-CeO2 samples were significantly lower than those of the Pd/meso-TiO2-CeO2 and Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 samples. Thus, the loading of Pt or Pd on meso-TiO2-CeO2 could effectively enhance the toluene conversion efficiency. The TOFNobel metal and TOFCe were calculated based on the catalytic activity data and the molar amounts of Pd or Pt and Ce in the meso-TiO2-CeO2, Pd/meso-TiO2-CeO2, and Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 samples, and their results are shown in Fig. 7 C and D. Additionally, the specific toluene reaction rates were also calculated, together with TOFNobel metal being listed in Table 3. The specific reaction rate and TOFNobel metal at 180 °C over the Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 sample were 3.92 mmol gPt −1 s−1 and 153.13 × 10−3 s−1, significantly higher than those (1.20 mmol gPd −1 s−1 and 25.56 × 10−3 s−1) over the Pd/meso-TiO2-CeO2 sample, respectively. The TOFCe values of the samples were in good consistency with their catalytic activity order (Fig. 7D), suggesting that the Ce acts as an active promoter in toluene oxidation over the Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 sample. The TOFNoble metal was considerably higher than the TOFCe, indicating that the Pt species were the primary active sites in the Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 sample. A review of literature on toluene oxidation over various catalysts (Table S2) reveals that the the specific toluene reaction rate at 160°C (1.80 mmol g−1 Pt s−1) or the specific toluene reaction rate at 180°C (3.92 mmol g−1 Pt s−1) of Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 or the specific toluene reaction rate at 180°C (1.20 mmol g−1 Pt s−1) of Pd/meso-TiO2-CeO2 is much higher than those at 160 or 180°C (0.7 ×10–2 mmol g−1 Pt s−1) of 2.3Pt/3DOM Mn2O3 [44], (0.3 ×10–2 mmol g−1 Pt s−1) of 0.12 wt% Pt1.9 nm/TiO2 [45], (0.11 mmol g−1 Pt s−1) of 0.96 wt% Pt/mZSM-5-A8 [46], (0.12 mmol g−1 Pt s−1) of 0.1 wt% Pt/Al2O3 (S) [47], and (0.5 ×10–2 mmol g−1 Pd s−1) of 3.26Pd-CoAlO-Al [48]. In summary, our Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 catalyst exhibited superior performance compared to most of the catalysts reported in the literature. To assess the catalytic stability, we conducted 30-h on-stream toluene oxidation experiments on the best-performing Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 sample at 215°C, as shown in Fig. S4 of the Supplementary material. Obviously, there was no significant loss in catalytic activity. Furthermore, the XPS results indicate that the surface Ce3+/Ce4+, Pt2+/Pt0, and Oads/Olatt molar ratios of the used sample after 100 h of toluene oxidation (Table 2 and Figs. 3 and 4) remained similar to those of the fresh sample. 3.5 Effect of water vapor To investigate the effect of moisture on catalytic activity of the samples, we introduced 5.0, 10.0 or 15.0 vol% water vapor into the reaction system, and maintained 30 h of toluene oxidation at the given temperatures. As shown in Fig. 8, catalytic activity of the meso-TiO2-CeO2 or meso-CeO2 sample was greatly affected by water vapor. Catalytic activity of the meso-CeO2 sample decreased gradually with the increase in water vapor concentration. After introduction of 5.0, 10.0, and 15.0 vol% water vapor, the conversion of toluene dropped first from 90 % to 72 %, then from 72 % to 61 %, and finally from 61 % to 30 %, respectively. When water vapor was removed, toluene conversion over meso-CeO2 did not return to the initial level achieved in the absence of water vapor. The same changing trend in catalytic activity was observed over the meso-TiO2-CeO2 sample. After the introduction of 5.0, 10.0, and 15.0 vol% water vapor, toluene conversion was decreased to 3, 18, and 40 %, respectively; furthermore, catalytic activity of meso-TiO2-CeO2 was not recovered when water vapor was cut off. However, toluene conversion over the Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 or Pd/meso-TiO2-CeO2 sample was almost unaffected after the addition of 5.0 vol% water vapor. With the introduction of 10.0 and 15.0 vol% water vapor, toluene conversions over Pd/meso-TiO2-CeO2 were decreased by ca. 3 and 7 %, respectively, while those over Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 were only decreased by ca. 2 and 4 %, respectively. After removing water vapor, catalytic activity of Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 or Pd/meso-TiO2-CeO2 was nearly fully restored. These results indicate that the Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 and Pd/meso-TiO2-CeO2 samples possess excellent water resistance under the high humidity condition. Clearly, the doping of titania to ceria and the loading of Pt or Pd on meso-TiO2-CeO2 could enhance water resistance in toluene oxidation, which was likely due to the generation of new reactive oxygen species facilitated by water on the Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 and Pd/meso-TiO2-CeO2 samples, thus promoting the toluene oxidation process. Fig. 9 systematically investigates the hydrothermal stability of synthesized catalysts in toluene oxidation under a 5 vol% H2O atmosphere. As shown in Fig. 9 A, both meso-CeO2 and meso-TiO2-CeO2 demonstrated limited catalytic activity, achieving maximum toluene conversion rates of 60 % and 68 %, respectively, without reaching complete mineralization. Notably, meso-TiO2-CeO2 exhibited progressive activity degradation under humid conditions, with a 22.3 % conversion decline after 24-hour testing. This moisture-induced deactivation stems from competitive adsorption between H2O and toluene molecules at low temperatures (<200°C), where hydroxyl groups preferentially occupy Brønsted acid sites, leading to irreversible structural collapse via surface hydroxylation. In contrast, Pd- and Pt-loaded meso-TiO2-CeO2 catalysts maintained > 98 % stable conversion efficiency throughout moisture exposure tests, showcasing exceptional hydrothermal stability attributed to metal-support interactions and protective site engineering. Additionally, Fig. 9B confirms the introduction of H2O was not influence the CO2 selectively. 3.6 Possible reaction pathway In situ DRIFTS is a good technique to measure the adsorbed reactants species and their reaction intermediates on a catalyst. After the samples were activated in an oxygen flow to remove water and carbon dioxide weakly adsorbed on the sample surface, we exposed these materials in a (1000 ppm toluene+20 vol% O2+N2 (balance)) flow at different temperatures and time, and their in situ DRIFTS spectra are presented in Fig. 10. As illustrated in the Fig. 10A, the bands at 2740, 2876, 2927, 3030, and 3072 cm−1 were assigned to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of the C-H of methyl group, C-H stretching vibration of the methyl group, isolated hydroxyl group, stretching vibration of the phenylic C-H in aromatic ring of toluene, and stretching vibration of the C-H bonds [49]. With the rise in temperature, some new peaks appeared. The bands at 1087, 1278, 1337, 1415, 1600, and 3723 cm−1 were attributed to the O2 2− species, the CO- stretching vibration of phenolate, the O−CO stretching vibrational modes of adsorbed carbonate species, benzoic acid, the in- and out-plane deformation vibrations of benzene ring in toluene, and isolated hydroxyl group [50]. Combined with the above results, we propose that toluene is first oxidized to form benzyl alcohol and benzoquinone, which are then converted to benzaldehyde, benzoic acid, and maleic anhydride, and these intermediates are finally oxidized to CO2 and H2O. As shown in Fig. 10C, the introduction of water vapor into the reaction gas mixture resulted in the detection of new absorption peaks on the catalyst surface. The peak at 3040 cm−1 is attributed to the C-H stretching vibration of the aromatic ring in toluene. The peaks at 2882 cm−1 and 2936 cm−1 correspond to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of methylene groups (-CH2-) in intermediate benzyl species [51]. The emergence of these peaks indicate that the methyl group (-CH3) of toluene undergoes partial oxidation during the reaction, generating intermediates containing methylene groups (e.g., benzyl alcohol). The peak at 1032 cm−1 is assigned to the C-O stretching vibration of oxygen-containing intermediates (e.g., methoxy or alcohol groups), while the peak at 1342 cm−1 is typically ascribed to the symmetric vibration of maleic anhydride (CO stretching) or carboxylate species. The peak at 3616 cm−1 is associated with the O-H stretching vibration of hydroxyl groups, likely originating from intermediates such as benzyl alcohol or benzoic acid. With increasing temperature, the gradual disappearance of the peaks at 1342 cm−1 and 3616 cm−1 suggests the rapid conversion of benzyl alcohol and benzoic acid. The introduction of water enhances the generation of benzyl alcohol but does not alter the primary reaction pathway of toluene. However, as the temperature rises, these intermediates are rapidly converted into CO₂ and H2O [52]. XRD and TEM analyses reveal that platinum (Pt) is highly dispersed within the ceria lattice, strengthening the electronic interactions between Pt and Ce/Ti species. This weakens the competitive adsorption of water on active Pt sites and provides abundant active sites, thereby enabling efficient catalytic oxidation of toluene. Under high humidity, the increased proportion of trivalent cerium (Ce3+) enhances the redox capacity of the catalyst and promotes the formation of oxygen vacancies. This intensifies the oxygen release capability of ceria, allowing the catalyst to maintain high activity even under high-humidity conditions. These results are consistent with results from XPS, EPR, and in-situ DRIFTS characterizations. 4 Conclusions In brief, the Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 and Pd/meso-TiO2-CeO2 catalysts were prepared by the in situ hard-templating method. The doping of titania to ceria and the loading of Pt or Pd on meso-TiO2-CeO2 exerted a substantial impact on the physicochemical property of meso-CeO2. The Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 catalyst showed the excellent catalytic performance (T 90 % = 214°C at SV = 30,000 mL g−1 h−1, TOFPt values and specific reaction rates at 160 and 180 °C were 70.34 × 10−3 and 153.13 × 10−3 s−1, and 1.80 and 3.92 mmol gPt −1 s−1, respectively) and the best water resistance for toluene oxidation under the high humidity (15 vol%) condition, which was mainly ascribed to its high surface area, abundant oxygen vacancies, high active oxygen species concentration, good low-temperature reducibility, and strong interaction between Pt or Pd and meso-TiO2-CeO2. Moreover, in situ DRIFTS results reveal that the possible mechanism of toluene oxidation over Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 follows the reaction sequence: Toluene is first oxidized to benzyl alcohol and benzoquinone, which are then converted to benzaldehyde, benzoic acid, maleic anhydride, and these intermediates are finally oxidized to CO2 and H2O. We believe that the present study can offer an important strategy for designing mesoporous mixed metal oxide-supported noble metal catalysts for the catalytic destruction of VOCs. coredata.dc:description: The major challenges encountered in developing catalysts for volatile organic compound (VOCs) treatments by catalytic oxidation are related to the low-temperature oxidation performance and water resistance. To address these issues, we herein develop an in situ hard-templating method to prepare the Pt or Pd/mesoporous TiO2-CeO2 catalyst and apply it for the oxidation of toluene. It was found that the Pt/mesoporous TiO2-CeO2 catalyst exhibited outstanding catalytic performance and stability under the high humidity (15 vol% H2O) condition. Various characterization results revealed that the Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic activity: the temperatures at toluene conversions of 50 and 90 % were 195 and 214 °C at a space velocity of 30,000 mL g−1 h−1, with the TOFPt values and specific reaction rates at 160 and 180 °C being 70.34 × 10−3 and 153.13 × 10−3 s−1, and 1.80 and 3.92 mmol gPt −1 s−1, respectively. Such excellent performance of Pt/meso-TiO2-CeO2 was related to its high surface area, abundant oxygen vacancies, high active oxygen species concentration, good low-temperature reducibility, and strong interaction between Pt or Pd and meso-TiO2-CeO2. The mechanism of toluene oxidation might take place via the following route: Toluene is first oxidized to benzyl alcohol and benzoquinone, then converted to benzaldehyde, benzoic acid, maleic anhydride, and these intermediates are finally oxidized to CO2 and H2O.
